import sympy
from sympy import symbols, diff, ln
from sympy.codegen.cfunctions import log2
import functools
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x0=symbols("x0")
x1=symbols("x1")

def call(f, x):
    return f(x)

def mapv(a, b):
    return list(map(a, map(lambda x: 1.0 * x, b)))

class PipeAsCall(object):
    def __init__(self, func):
        self.func = func
    def __or__(self, other):
        return self.func(other)
    def __call__(self, x):
        return self.func(x)

def partial(*args):
    return PipeAsCall(
        functools.partial(*args))

def D(f):
  var = symbols("var")
  return PipeAsCall(sympy.lambdify([var], diff(f(var), var), "sympy"))

def rnd(expr):
     return expr.xreplace({n: round(n, 3) for n in expr.atoms(sympy.Number)})

def plot(f, x):
    plt.plot(x, mapv(f, x), "o")

<div class="desc" id="blocklyDiv5_t">
I start with the formula that has been found over the centuries by stronger souls then us. The combination of music and math begins 500 BCE with Pythagoras. -- I needed to wrap this formula into a procedure. For this you have to make a decision. You have to choose names. Naming is hard. The procedure itself I give the name Poe. It takes the arguments intersect, steps and the frequency x. The procedure returns the formula. -- You have to replace the numbers by the chosen names. -- I provide the procedure as Python code. -- Now the procedure can be called with the numbers. -- Or with other numbers.
</div>

The procedure I named Poe cannot be plot directly. Only mathematical objects can be drawn. To make a mathematical object out of Poe, you use a procedure named partial. -- Only then can you plot the log2. -- Here is the main theme in spades. Partial taking a procedure to deliver the math to plot.

    return partial(Poe, intersect, steps)
